特記事項:
本授業科目は、“オンライン授業60単位制限対象科目”ではありません。
The course is not subject to the 60-credit limit for online courses.
授業方法: Depending on enrollment numbers, the evolving COVID-19 situation, and the schedule of students at Trinity University, this course should be mostly face to face, with a hybrid, online option, if needed. Most classes will involve a lecture component followed by whole-class and small-group discussions. Groups will sometimes be asked to make impromptu speeches to summarize the contents of discussion. The final few classes of the semester will be dedicated to student presentations. You should have a stable wifi or internet connection at home to complete all out-of-class assignments. The course will also involve at least two LIVE online sessions with students at Trinity University.

第1回:
**The course contents are subject to change dependent on the information received from the students' needs analyses. The needs analyses will be done during the first class of the semester.
Icebreakers: Students get to know each other. Students learn about the course and the background of the US-based students.



Students will complete two sections of this course: 1) intercultural communication foundations, and 2) applied intercultural communication. First, the foundations component of the course will involve the role of culture in communication and how intercultural competences may improve the chances of successful cross-cultural interactions, especially in Japan. With an understanding of culture as distinct, yet fluid, the second stage of the course examines the intercultural foundations in practice.

Introductions, ice breakers, needs analysis

In principle, all 14 sessions will be conducted face to face
Needs analysis survey: 1 hour
第2回:
Understanding differences between cultures
What is culture and intercultural communication?
Culture as an iceberg: focus on perspectives (i.e. deep culture)
Developing questions / discussion themes for first COIL session based on deep culture.
Reflect on “Cool Japan” initiative

Homework assignments include weekly journals of at least 350 words that provide the basis for the following week’s lesson. Essentially, the journal assignment will allow students to prepare for the following week’s discussion.
Journal 1: 1-2 hours
第3回:
First COIL interaction
Create rotating discussion circles via Zoom.
Set period of time for introductory discussion.
Provide discussion prompts based on class 2 preparations and homework.
第4回:
First First COIL reflection; Hofstede model of national culture
Reflect: I used to think (about Texas / USA) but now I know…
Introduce Hofstede’s Theory on national culture.
第5回:
Challenge national culture models: Does country = culture?
Teach students the Describe Interpretation Evaluate technique.
Ask students to identify visual media about Japan and the USA to be discussed in COIL #2.
第6回:
Second COIL interaction.
Create rotating discussion circles via Zoom.
Set period of time for DIE discussions.
Japanese students share DIE of US media; US-based students respond.
US-based students share DIE of Japanese media; Japan-based students respond.
第7回:
Second COIL reflection
Reflect: Most valuable lessons learned in terms of culture and language developments.
Goal setting for in-class face-to-face interactions via Possible selves (ideal L2, ought to L2, etc.).
Discussion of identity and its role in intercultural communication: minority vs majority identity development.
第8回:
**Classes 8-11 represent the second phase of this course, which involves discussions on various cross-cultural issues
Intercultural Communication Discussion #1
Theme: gender and sexuality
第9回:
Intercultural Communication Discussion #2
Theme: representation of culture and nationality in media
第10回:
Intercultural Communication Discussion #3
Theme: autobiography of intercultural encounters
第11回:
Intercultural Communication Discussion #4
Theme: The higher education experience - comparing Japan and the C2
第12回: Research, prepare, and deliver final presentation: 15-20 hours (approximately)
